jstat.data.Document.html:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox political party |name = Yisrael Beiteinu |native_name = ????? ????? |logo = [[File:Israel-beytenu-logo.jpg|Yisrael Beiteinu party logo]] |leader = [[Avigdor Lieberman]] |founded = 1999 |headquarters = [[Jerusalem]], Israel |ideology = Nationalism,{{cite web|url=http://www.knesset.gov.il/faction/eng/FactionPage_eng.asp?PG=101 |title=A nationalist list, made up of new immigrants and old-timers and headed by MK Avigdor Lieberman, that ran in the elections for the Fifteenth Knesset |publisher=Knesset.gov.il |accessdate=25 April 2010}}
[[Revisionist Zionism]]http://www.yisraelbeytenu.com/#bringing
[[Secularism]],{{cite web|url=http://beytenu.org/107/1172/article.html |title=Lenience within the Halakha (religious law) |publisher=Beytenu.org |accessdate=25 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Politics/Yisraelbeitenu.html |title=Regarding religious issues in Israel, the party does not call for the separation of religion and state. |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org |accessdate=25 April 2010}}
[[Economic liberalism]],http://www.yisraelbeytenu.com/#raising{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Politics/Yisraelbeitenu.html |title=Yisrael Beiteinu supports the advancement of free-market economic policies |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org |accessdate=25 April 2010}}
[[Lieberman Plan]],
[[Russian Jewish immigration to Israel in the 1990s|Russian-speakers]]' interests,{{cite web|url=http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/mideast/RL33476.pdf |title=Israel: Background and Relations with the United States |format=PDF |accessdate=25 April 2010}} |position = |affiliation1_title = Alliance |affiliation1 = [[National Union (Israel)|National Union]] (20002006),
[[Likud Yisrael Beiteinu]] (2012) |colors = |seats1_title = [[Knesset]] |seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|15|120|hex=#3D107B}} |symbol = ? |website = [http://www.beytenu.org/ www.beytenu.org] |colorcode = #3D107B |country = Israel }} '''Yisrael Beiteinu''' ({{lang-he|????? ?????}}, lit. ''Israel Our Home'') is a nationalist [[List of political parties in Israel|political party]] in Israel. The party's base has traditionally been secular, Russian-speaking Israelis. The party describes itself as "a national movement with the clear vision to follow in the brave path of [[Ze'ev Jabotinsky|Zev Jabotinsky]]",[http://www.yisraelbeytenu.com/#bringing Bringing the Zionist Dream to Life] Party website the founder of [[Revisionist Zionism]]. Although it represents immigrants from the former [[Soviet Union]],http://fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/121830.pdf it has also expanded its appeal to a more veteran Israeli public.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3605239,00.html |title=Singer Arik Sinai joins Yisrael Beiteinu |work=Ynetnews |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=25 April 2010}} It takes a strong line towards the peace process and the integration of [[Arab citizens of Israel|Israeli Arabs]], characterized by its [[Israeli legislative election, 2009|2009 election]] slogan "No loyalty, no citizenship".{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1062611.html |title=Lieberman now throwing his 'no loyalty, no citizenship' motto at Shas Haaretz Israel News |work=Haaretz |accessdate=25 April 2010}} Its main platform includes a recognition of the [[two-state solution]], the creation of a Palestinian state that would [[Lieberman Plan|include an exchange]] of some largely Arab-inhabited parts of Israel for largely Jewish-inhabited parts of the West Bank.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1233304732216 Background: Beyond Israel Beiteinu's campaign slogans] The party maintains an [[anti-clerical]] mantle and encourages socio-economic opportunities for new immigrants, in conjunction with efforts to increase [[Aliyah|Jewish immigration]]. In the elections the party won 15 seats, its most to date, making it the third largest party in the [[Knesset]].{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1063744.html |title=Final election results: Kadima 28 seats, Likud 27, Yisrael Beiteinu 15 |work=Haaretz |location=Israel |accessdate=25 April 2010}} ==History== [[File:Avigdor Lieberman.jpg|thumb|110px|[[Avigdor Lieberman]], [[Israeli Minister of Foreign Affairs|Minister of Foreign Affairs]]]] [[File:Hamed Amar.jpg|thumb|110px||[[Hamad Amar]]]] [[File:Anastassia Michaeli.jpg|thumb|110px|[[Anastassia Michaeli]]]] [[file:Orli Levi 003.jpg|thumb|110px|[[Orly Levi]], Deputy [[Speaker of the Knesset]]]] [[File:Uzi Landau 001.jpg|thumb|110px|[[Uzi Landau]], [[Energy and Water Resources Ministry|Minister of Energy and Water Resources]]]] [[File:Izhak Aronovich 007.jpg|thumb|110px|[[Yitzhak Aharonovich]], [[Ministry of Public Security (Israel)|Minister of Internal Security]]]] Yisrael Beiteinu was formed by [[Avigdor Lieberman]] to create a platform for [[Russia]]n immigrants who support a hard line in negotiations with the Palestinian Authority. Lieberman's actions were motivated by the concessions granted by his former boss, [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] (when he was director-general of the Likud) to the Palestinian Authority in the 1997 [[Wye River Memorandum]], featuring the division of the West Bank city of [[Hebron]]. One of the partners in Netanyahu's coalition was [[Yisrael BaAliyah]], a new immigrants' list led by [[Natan Sharansky]] that also had right-of-center leanings. After Lieberman left Likud, he registered great disappointment when Sharansky did not pull out of the coalition, as did two of Sharansky's colleagues in Yisrael BaAliyah, [[Michael Nudelman]] and [[Yuri Stern]], both of whom broke away to form [[Aliyah (political party)|Aliyah]]. For the [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|1999 elections]], Lieberman, Nudelman and Stern formed Yisrael Beiteinu, and the new party won four seats. On 1 February 2000 the party joined an alliace with the [[National Union (Israel)|National Union]],[http://www.knesset.gov.il/faction/eng/FactionHistoryAll_eng.asp Mergers and Splits Among Parliamentary Groups] Knesset website itself an alliance of right-wing parties led by [[Binyamin Elon]]. In the 2003 elections the joint list won seven seats, with Yisrael Beiteinu being given four of them. The alliance joined [[Ariel Sharon]]'s government and Lieberman was made [[Transportation Minister of Israel|Minister of Transport]]. However, the party left the government on 6 June 2004,[http://www.knesset.gov.il/govt/eng/GovtByNumber_eng.asp?govt=30 Sixteenth Knesset: Government 30] Knesset website in response to the [[Israel's unilateral disengagement plan|disengagement plan]]. On 1 February 2006, shortly before the [[Israeli legislative election, 2006|elections that year]], the party split from National Union in order to run alone in the elections. The election results saw the party increase in strength to eleven seats. Although it remained outside [[Ehud Olmert]]'s government formed in May 2006, it joined the coalition in October 2006. The party was involved in a controversy in January 2007 after [[Israeli Labor Party|Labor Party]] leader [[Amir Peretz]] nominated [[Raleb Majadele]] for the position of [[Science, Culture and Sport Minister of Israel|Minister of Science and Technology]], thereby making him Israel's first Muslim Arab minister.[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/812447.html Lieberman calls on Peretz to quit over appointment of first Arab minister] Haaretz, 12 January 2007 Lieberman condemned the nomination and called for Peretz's resignation, accusing him of harming Israel's security by ceding to "internal rivalries" within the Labour party, whilst Peretz accused Yisrael Beiteinu of being a racist party.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1167467737898 Peretz: Israel Beiteinu 'racist party'] Jerusalem Post, 16 January 2007 Yisrael Beiteinu's member of Knesset (MK) [[Esterina Tartman]] referred to Peretz's decision as a "lethal blow to Zionism," adding that Majadale's presence in the [[Cabinet of Israel|cabinet]] would damage "Israel's character as a Jewish state" and that "We need to destroy this affliction from within ourselves. God willing, God will come to our help." Tartman's comments were immediately condemned as racist by other MKs.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6254691.stm Israel names first Arab minister] BBC News, 12 January 2007 In January 2008 the party left the government in protest against talks with the [[Palestinian National Authority]], saying certain issues negotiated were not to be tolerated.[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/945299.html Lieberman blasts Arab MKs, pulls party out of government] Haaretz, 16 January 2008 Lieberman pulled out of the government and left his position as Minister of Strategic Affairs, and almost immediately afterwards, ''Arutz Sheva'' reported that an investigation against Lieberman and his daughter that had been "ongoing for years, suddenly became active again once he left the government last week."[http://209.85.129.104/search?q=cache:N1CYDILLtoYJ:www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/125032+%22The+investigation+against+Lieberman+and+his+daughter+have+been+ongoing+for+years,+but+suddenly+became+active+again+once+he+left+the+government+last+week.%22+site:israelnationalnews.com&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=1 Expos Links Olmert, Lieberman and Sharon to Jericho Casino] Israel National News, 24 January 2008 On 22 December 2008, Lieberman approved the party's list for the [[Israeli legislative election, 2009|2009 elections]]. New names in the top ten include [[Orly Levy]] (daughter of former [[Likud]] MK [[David Levy (Israeli politician)|David Levy]]) and [[Anastasia Michaeli]], two former models and current television hosts. Knesset members [[Yosef Shagal]] and Tartman failed to make the list.{{Cite news |last = Branovsky |first = Yael |title = Lieberman to approve Yisrael Beiteinu roster |work = Ynetnews |accessdate = 23 December 2008 |date = 22 December 2008 |url = http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3642639,00.html }} The results of the election saw the party win 15 seats, making it the third largest after Kadima (28) and Likud (27). In March 2009, Yisrael Beiteinu joined Binyamin Netanyahu's coalition and party leader Avigdor Lieberman became Deputy Prime Minister and [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Foreign Affairs Minister]], whilst the party received four other ministerial portfolios, and one deputy minister post. On 25 October 2012, Lieberman and Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] announced that Yisrael Beiteinu and [[Likud]] would run together on a single ballot in Israel's 22 January 2013 general elections. In view of the challenges were facing, we need responsibility on a national level ... Were providing a true alternative, and an opportunity for the citizens to stabilize leadership and government., Lieberman said.{{cite web|last=Leshem|first=Elie|title=Netanyahu, Liberman announce theyll run joint list for Knesset|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-announces-merger-with-israel-beytenu-promises-to-lead-with-strength/|publisher=The Times of Israel|accessdate=27 October 2012}} ==Organization== The supreme body in the party is the party conference which convenes every four years. The participants of the party choose the institutions of the party and among them the party court, the permanent commission, the municipal commission, and the [[comptroller]]. Yisrael Beiteinu runs for local elections under the name of the city that they run in, e.g. [[Petah Tikva]] Beiteinu ("Petah Tikva Our Home"). ==Policies== ===Relations with Israeli Arabs and Palestinians=== {{Main|Lieberman Plan}} One of the party's main policies is that of drawing the borders in such a way that areas with large Arab populations, such as [[Triangle (Israel)|the Triangle area]] and the [[Wadi Ara]], both gained by Israel as part of the [[1949 Armistice Agreements]], would be transferred to Arab sovereignty. Known as the [[Lieberman Plan]], such an arrangement would mean that the majority of Jews would live in Israel and the majority of Arabs would live in a future Palestinian state. In most cases there is no physical population transfer or demolition of houses, but creating a new border where none existed before, according to demographics.{{cite news|last=Liberman|first=Avigdor|title=My blueprint for a resolution|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Op-EdContributors/Article.aspx?id=179333|accessdate=14 May 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=23 June 2010}} United Nations General Assembly Resolution 55/153, written in 2001, explicitly states: When part of the territory of a state is transferred by that state to another state, the successor state shall attribute its nationality to the persons concerned who have their habitual residence in the transferred territory and the predecessor state shall withdraw its nationality from such persons, and Lieberman claims that this means Israel can legally transfer territory and citizens as a means of peace and ultimate conflict resolution. [[Avigdor Lieberman|Avigdor Liberman]] argues that the Arab residents see themselves not as Israelis but as Palestinians, and should therefore be encouraged to join the [[Palestinian Authority]]. Lieberman has presented this proposal as part of a potential peace deal aimed at establishing [[Two-state solution|two separate national entities]], one for Jews in Israel and the other for Arabs in Palestine. However, he is known to have an affinity for and is popular amongst the [[Druze]] population (the only Arab population to be fully drafted into the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]]), and has attracted a number of Druze voters, including some in the [[Golan Heights]] who voted for the party in protest.[http://www.ynet.co.il/english/articles/0,7340,L-3670904,00.html Druze in Golan vote Lieberman out of 'protest'] Yedioth Ahronoth, 12 February 2009 Druze candidate Hamad Amar was elected to the Knesset on the party's list in 2009.[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1062747.html Meet [[Hamad Amar]], Yisrael Beiteinu's Druze candidate] Haaretz, 9 February 2009 Regarding [[Palestinian statehood]], Liberman has said that he supports the creation of "a viable Palestinian state".[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1067299.html Lieberman: I support creation of viable Palestinian state] Haaretz, 27 February 2009 ====Nakba Day reform==== Yisrael Beytenu was instrumental in passing a law which would fine bodies that receive state funding being spent in recognition of [[Nakba Day]], and events that call for the end of Israel as a Jewish State.{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/objects/pages/PrintArticleEn.jhtml?itemNo=1085588 |title=Lieberman's party proposes ban on Arab Nakba |date=15 May 2009 |work=[[Haaretz]]}}Bronner, Ethan. [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/01/world/middleeast/01mideast.html?scp=2&sq=Nakba&st=nyt 6 Die as Palestinian Authority Forces Clash With Hamas ], ''The New York Times'', 31 May 2009. ===The Iranian nuclear program=== Yisrael Beytenu has taken a strong stance against the growth and development of the [[Iranian nuclear program]]. Liberman has made clear that "there are no illusions as to the Iranians' intentions regarding their military nuclear program," after meeting US Homeland Security Secretary [[Janet Napolitano]] in [[Jerusalem]]. Liberman and the party have worked hard and collaborated with many world leaders in order to keep the issue at the top of the global agenda and to increase international pressure. I do not believe the international community is under any illusions regarding Iran's willingness to give up its nuclear program," Liberman said. {{cite web|title=Lieberman: Iran trying to deceive West|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4231318,00.html|publisher=YNet News|accessdate=6 June 2012}} ===Government reform=== A long-time and current standing goal of the party has been government reform. Yisrael Beytenu, since its inception, has called for the separation of the legislative and executive branches to increase accountability and uniformity within government. [[Danny Ayalon]], Deputy Foreign Minister, MK, and former international party chair, explained the partys call for reform; In Israel, there is no sufficient separation of powers. Around a third of [[the Knesset]] Members serve as ministers or deputy ministers and are thus forbidden to introduce laws or participate in committees. There are few apposite checks and balances, in fact, farcically, the opposite is true; as an MK, I am expected to conduct oversight of my role as Deputy Foreign Minister. Between an impending nuclear Iran and the rising cost of living within Israel proper, Yisrael Beytenu has been committed to finding a solution within the Knesset that will allow for action to be taken.{{cite web|last=Ayalon|first=Danny|title=Preventing the political system's stagnation, collapse|url=http://www.dannyayalon.com/Publications/441/|accessdate=6/62012}} The people want change, and are sick and tired of all the wheeling and dealing within the coalition that is necessary to pass the simplest of laws, Ayalon further explains.{{cite news|last=Ayalon|first=Danny|title=Desperately Seeking Political Courage|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Op-EdContributors/Article.aspx?id=207952|accessdate=6 June 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=12 February 2011}} ====The Norwegian law==== As the party seeks to increase governability, it supports the passage of the Norwegian Law that will require MKs to resign their seats when appointed a Ministerial position and be replaced by another party member.{{cite web|title=Our Policies in Brief|url=http://www.beytenu.org/content/Our_Policies_in_Brief|publisher=Yisrael Beytenu|accessdate=6 June 2012}}{{cite news|last=Hoffman|first=Gil|title=Norwegian law passage may cause ministerial war|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=146514|accessdate=6 June 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=24 June 2009}} ===Relations with Gaza=== Yisrael Beytenu advocates the complete cutting of ties with [[Gaza]] and its separation from the [[West Bank]]. ===Religion and state=== Yisrael Beytenu does not advocate a separation of religion and state, but rather seeks to moderate the [[Chief Rabbinate of Israel|Israeli rabbinate]]. Following an attempt to delegitimize the conversion of soldiers that were made through the authority of the army's chief rabbi, MKs [[David Rotem]] and [[Robert Ilatov]] led the party in the passing of the a bill that formally legalized the conversions.{{cite web|title=Bill to Universally Recognize Army Conversions Approved|url=http://www.beytenu.org/content/Bill_to_Universally_Recognize_Army_Conversions_Approved|publisher=Yisrael Beytenu|accessdate=20 May 2012}} The party is also working to make marriage easier for secular Israelis by working to pass the The Tzohar Law. The new law will end the restriction of Jewish couples to be wedded only by the rabbi of their locale, permitting them to choose any recognized rabbi in the country to perform their marriage. This will allow the couple to avoid the often burdensome bureaucracy associated with the marriage process.{{cite news|last=Yanover|first=Yori|title=New Knesset Tzohar Law to Curtail Chief Rabbinates Control on Weddings Passes First Reading|url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/breaking-news/new-knesset-tzohar-law-to-curtail-chief-rabbinates-control-on-weddings-passes-first-reading/2012/05/22/0/?print|accessdate=23 May 2012|newspaper=The Jewish Press|date=29 May 2012}} ===Conversion Bill=== Yisrael Beytenu, particularly MK [[David Rotem]], has promoted reforming the [[Law of Return]], which would undertake the following measures: *Potentially but not officially make the Law of Return applicable exclusively to born Jews, and Orthodox Converts as well as their offspring rather than converts to mainline sects of Judaism from other religions if those converts visited Israel at any point prior to conversion *Make clearer delineations between the Law of Return and the Citizenship Law *Broaden the power of the [[Chief Rabbinate of Israel]] by authorizing Chief Rabbinate-appointed municipal rabbis to carry out conversions and marriages for the converted{{cite web|last=Ettinger |first=Yair |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/new-bill-would-make-conversion-insufficient-for-israeli-citizenship-1.266361 |title=''New bill would make conversion insufficient for Israeli citizenship'' |work=Haaretz |date=7 March 2010 |accessdate=2012-12-17}} The Conversion Bill has been heavily criticized by various religious groups in both Israel and other countries; [[Shas]] and [[United Torah Judaism]] initially balked at the bill due to perceived contradictions against Jewish law, but eventually reached a compromise.{{cite web|author='+relative_time(twitters[i].created_at)+' |url=http://blogs.rj.org/rac/2010/04/new_bill_would_be_disastrous_t.html |title=''New Bill Would be "Disastrous to the Unity of the Jewish People"'' |publisher=Blogs.rj.org |date=30 April 2010 |accessdate=2012-12-17}} Conservative, Reform and Reconstructionist movement heavily objected against the bill's further centering of religious power in the hands of the predominately-Orthodox Chief Rabbinate of Israel, discriminating against converts to Progressive Judaism and potentially alienating non-Orthodox Jews in the [[Jewish diaspora]]. ===Other policies=== MK [[Lia Shemtov]] is known for her opposition to the Israeli [[welfare-to-work]] plan (known as the "Wisconsin Plan"), along with the rest of the party. The party also supports increasing the [[Israel Police|police force]], improving education, easing conversions and secular/non-religious civil unions.The party's platform http://www.beytenu.org/107/2193/article.html The last two points are particularly popular with the Russian immigrant community who vote heavily for the party.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} These items angered some of the religious parties such as Shas with Shas's Rabbi Ovadia Yossef claiming that "Whoever votes for Lieberman gives strength to Satan," and claims that the party is a danger to religious matters in Israel.Shas' Rabbi Yosef: Voting for Lieberman gives strength to Satan http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1062315.html While the party as a whole does not advocate the separation of religion and state, the local chapters generally push for measures that the religious public opposes, such as [[Shabbat#Prohibited activities|public transportation on Saturdays]] and the ability to sell pork (which is [[Kashrut|treif]] and [[haraam]]) in general stores. ==Perception== A number of [[mainstream media]] sources, within and outside of Israel, have labelled the party, and Lieberman, as [[Right-wing politics|right wing]] and even far right or [[Ultra-nationalists|ultra nationalist]].[http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2008Oct29/0,4670,MLIsraelMubarak,00.html Israel apologizes for lawmaker's Mubarak comments] Fox News 29 October 2008[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6098310.stm Far-right joins Israel coalition] BBC News, 30 October 2006[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/4526533/Far-Right-Israeli-party-enjoys-surge-in-polls-to-become-election-kingmaker.html Far-Right Israeli party enjoys surge in polls to become election kingmaker] The Telegraph, 6 February 2009[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2006/mar/30/israel2 Olmert seeks partners after indecisive victory] The Guardian, 30 March 2006[http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasen/spages/1057752.html How did Kadima lost four seats in one week?] Haaretz[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1229868806768 Yisrael Beitenu list: Two famous models, one disappointed ambassador] The Jerusalem Post, 23 December 2008[http://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/23/world/middleeast/24mideastcnd.html Israeli Adds Far-Right Party to Coalition] New York Times, 23 October 2006[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article5636047.ece Israel: Hardline nationalists savour pre-election boost in polls] The Times, 2 February 2009[http://www.france24.com/france24Public/en/archives/news/middle-east/20080116-israel-lieberman-ultranationalist-resignation-government-olmert-opposition.php Ultra-nationalist party quits Israeli coalition govt] France 24, 16 January 2008[http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2009Feb04/0,4670,MLIsraelHardlineHero,00.html Israeli ultranationalist poised for election gains] Fox News, 4 February 2009[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6098310.stm Far-right joins Israel coalition ] BBC News[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1400139/Whos-who-Israeli-groups.html Who's who: Israeli groups] The Telegraph[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/dec/27/israel-nationalism-beiteinu-likud-gaza Israeli far right gains ground as Gaza rockets fuel tension] The Guardian, 27 December 2008[http://www.newsweek.com/id/183698 The Palin of Israel] Newsweek, 7 February 2009[http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=100436058 Israeli Ultranationalist Expected To Gain In Election] NPR, 9 February 2009[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2006-11/01/content_5278211.htm Abbas, Haneya slam Israel's new round of Gaza offensive] Xinhua, 1 November 2006 At the same time however, the party does recognize a [[two-state solution]] and it is a [[secularism|secular]] Party, with some of its particular religious policies described as "ultra liberal".[http://www.ufppc.org/content/view/8405/35/ NEWS: Livni demands rotating prime ministerial post; Lieberman wants defense or foreign] United for Peace These positions are contradictory to the tradition of both nationalistic and religious right wing politics in Israel. Some have called the party and its leader a "hard-line" or "self-styled" [[populism|populist]].[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/1533343/Jews-and-Arabs-can-never-live-together%2C-says-Israel%27s-vice-PM.html Jews and Arabs can never live together, says Israel's vice PM] The Telegraph[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/feb/05/israel-election-lieberman-opinion-polls Hardline populist Lieberman could be surprise kingmaker in Israeli election] The Guardian, 5 February 2009[http://www.reuters.com/article/russia/idUSTRE5170SV20090208 Israeli populist's hardline message draws voters] Reuters, 8 February 2009[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1550372,00.html Olmert's New Coalition Partner: A Step Forward or Back?] Time, 24 October 2006 While various Arab and world media and politicians accused the party and its leader of being a fascist and racist,[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1159193489732 Olmert, Lieberman sign coalition deal] The Jerusalem Post, 22 October 2006[http://www.antiwar.com/justin/?articleid=9923 A Jewish Hitler?] Antiwar, 27 October 2006[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1139395652473&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Arab MK calls Lieberman a 'fascist'] The Jerusalem Post, 22 March 2006[http://www.forward.com/articles/15173/ Beiteinu Now Big Player] Jewish Daily Forward, 11 February 2009[http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-02-11-voa45.cfm Arabs Pessimistic About Israeli Elections] VOA News, 11 February 2009 a number of Israeli media and politicians tend to disagree,[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1233304740316&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull 'Lieberman isn't racist, Hamas is'] The Jerusalem Post, 11 February 2009[http://news.haaretz.co.il/hasen/pages/ShArtStEngPE.jhtml?itemNo=830503&contrassID=2&subContrassID=5&title=%27Not%20racist,%20stigmatized%20%27&dyn_server=172.20.5.5 Not racist, stigmatized] Haaretz[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1233304768730 Is Avigdor Lieberman a racist? No, but...] The Jerusalem Post, 14 February 2009 and some even offered praise on occasion. For example, [[Kadima]]'s [[Finance Minister of Israel|Minister of Finance]] [[Roni Bar-On]] said "It's a Jewish party, Zionist and serious."[http://archive.gulfnews.com/indepth/israelielection/more_stories/10030825.html Olmert may include ultra-nationalist party in coalition] Gulf News, 5 April 2006 The party phenomenon was explained by [[Gershom Gorenberg]]:"[http://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200704u/avigdor-lieberman Israel Our Home] The Atlantic, 14 March 2007 :Lieberman is not a right-winger, because hes talking about giving up land. In fact, hes even willing to give up land from sovereign Israel. [..] I think one of the reasons people say Lieberman is in the center is that they dont realize he has, in effect, redefined the terms. In a February 2009 address considered to be directed at the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]], Avigdor Lieberman stated that Yisrael Beiteinu was neither far-right, nor ultra-nationalist.{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3678374,00.html|title=Lieberman: I Back the Creation of Palestinian State|publisher=[[Ynetnews]]|author=Benhorin, Yitzhak|date=26 February 2009|accessdate=27 February 2009}} Yehuda Ben-Meir wrote in the left-wing ''[[Haaretz]]'' that he did not and would not ever vote for Lieberman. He also criticized the delegitimizing and demonizing of both the right and the left:
Lieberman is neither a racist nor a fascist, and depicting him as such does an injustice to his voters and harm to Israel.
What's racist is denying the Jewish people a state of their own. Certain Arab Knesset members talk incessantly about the Palestinian people's rights, including their own state. But in the same breath they refuse to acknowledge Israel as the state of the Jewish people and deny the very existence of a Jewish people as a nation with national rights...
Just as we must condemn right wingers' attempts to cast doubt over the patriotism of [[Yossi Beilin]] and his fellow subscribers to the Geneva Initiative provocative as this plan might be to most Israelis we must condemn the left's lamentable habit of denigrating Lieberman. The idea to change the state's borders in a peace agreement may not be practical or implementable in our circumstances, but we cannot deny its legitimacy and sense. And in any case, it has nothing to do with racism. Lieberman has said publicly that he supports the principle of establishing a Palestinian state.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1081038.html|title=Lieberman is no racist|author=Yehuda Ben-Meir|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=26 April 2009}}
According to [[Time (magazine)|Time.com]], many Russian immigrants are attracted to the ideas of Lieberman's party. It also notes that analysts say that at this time "the dreary prospects for peace, and recent terrorist attacks inflicted by Israeli Arabs" have contributed to Lieberman's popularity among other segments of Israeli society.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/video/?bcpid=1485842900&bctid=11823475001 |title=Israel's Kingmaker |work=Time |accessdate=25 April 2010}} ===Criticism=== Yisrael Beiteinu and its plan have many vehement critics from the left and the right in Israel. Despite its support for increased Jewish immigration ([[aliyah]]) and settlement expansion, Yisrael Beiteinu's platform is based in part on the creation of a [[two-state solution|Palestinian state adjacent to Israel]], and thus has alienated much of the religious right-wing settlement movement which refuses to acknowledge Palestinian claims to any of the 'Land of Israel.' Yisrael Beiteinu has drawn equally strong criticism from the Left, in large part due to the [[Lieberman Plan]]'s proposed land and population transfers along ethnic lines. This focus on ethnicity and religion has drawn comparisons with the now defunct [[Kach and Kahane Chai|Kach]] party.[http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/opinion/kahane-won-1.269642 Kahane Won] Haaretz, 2 August 2009[http://www.haaretz.com/news/elections/israel-s-mr-tv-likens-lieberman-to-slain-anti-arab-extremist-kahane-1.266850 Israel's 'Mr. TV' likens Lieberman to slain anti-Arab extremist Kahane] Haaretz, 1 January 2009 The [[Lieberman Plan]] caused a stir among Arab citizens of Israel, which explicitly treats them as a 'fifth column' and as an enemy within. With few exceptions, Arabs in Israel argue that they have lived in the region for centuries, and should not have to renounce the villages and cities in which they, their parents, and their grandparents were born (although the plan calls for a transfer of sovereignty, rather than population). Others insist that as Israeli citizens, they deserve equal rights within the State, and should not be singled out according to their ethnic or religious background. Various polls show that Arabs in Israel in general do not wish to move to the West Bank or Gaza if a Palestinian state were created there.[http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/03/23/opinion/eddromi.php Israeli Arabs and the Vote] International Herald Tribune, 24 March 2006 ==Allegations of anti-Arabism== {{See also|Anti-Arabism}} Two Israeli Arab journalists were excluded from a campaign gathering held by Yisrael Beiteinu in [[Haifa]]. [[Haifa]] Deputy Mayor Yulia Shtraim, a member of the party's municipal faction, said she would not allow the journalists to enter the hall "because of the Arabs' demonstration and what [the demonstrators] say about [[Avigdor Lieberman|Lieberman]]." The Israeli Arab journalists were denied access, despite possessing press cards, being told that they were uninvited. However uninvited Jewish and foreign media were allowed in.{{cite news |title=Arab reporters banned from campaign meet of Lieberman's far-right party |coauthors=Fadi Eyadat and Lily Galili |work=[[Haaretz]] |date=10 February 2009 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1062998.html}} Young fans waiting outside a Yisrael Beiteinu conference shouted the slogans "No loyalty, no citizenship" and "Death to Arabs" at passersby. One of the youths explained that they meant death to those who support terror.{{cite news |title=Lieberman's anti-Arab ideology wins over Israel's teens |first=Yotam |last=Feldman |work=[[Haaretz]] |date=7 February 2009 |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1061910.html}} ==Knesset members== [[File:Ballot2009 YB.jpg|thumb|150px|YB party ballot 2009]] The party currently has 15 Knesset members. #[[Avigdor Lieberman]] #[[Uzi Landau]] #[[Stas Misezhnikov]] #[[Yitzhak Aharonovich]] #[[Sofa Landver]] #[[Orly Levy]] #[[Danny Ayalon]] #[[David Rotem]] #[[Anastasia Michaeli]] #[[Faina Kirschenbaum]] #[[Robert Ilatov]] #[[Hamad Amar]] #[[Moshe Mutz Matlon]] #[[Lia Shemtov]] #[[Alex Miller (Israeli politician)|Alex Miller]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} *{{Official website|http://www.beytenu.org.il/}} {{he icon}} *{{Official website|http://www.beytenu.org/e}} {{en icon}} *{{Official website|http://www.ndi.org.il/}} {{ru icon}} *[http://www.knesset.gov.il/faction/eng/FactionPage_eng.asp?PG=101 Yisrael Beiteinu] Knesset website {{Israeli political parties}} [[Category:Political parties established in 1999]] [[Category:Political parties in Israel]] [[Category:Zionist political parties in Israel]] [[Category:Nationalist parties]] [[Category:Secularism in Israel]] [[Category:Secularist political parties]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Israel]] [[Category:Revisionist Zionism]] {{Link FA|pl}} [[ar:??? ??????? ?????]] [[ca:Yisrael Betenu]] [[cs:Jisra'el bejtejnu]] [[da:Yisrael Beytenu]] [[de:Jisra'el Beitenu]] [[et:Yisra'el Betenu]] [[es:Israel Beitenu]] [[fo:Yisrael Beiteinu]] [[fr:Israel Beytenou]] [[it:Israel Beytenu]] [[he:????? ?????]] [[lad:Yisrael Beiteinu]] [[la:Yisrael Beiteinu]] [[nl:Jisrael Beetnoe]] [[ja:????????]] [[no:Yisrael Beitenu]] [[pl:Yisrael Beitenu]] [[pt:Yisrael Beitenu]] [[ru:??? ??? ???????]] [[fi:Jisrael Beiteinu]] [[sv:Yisrael Beiteinu]] [[uk:??? ??? ???????]] [[zh:????????]]
